definition.name: Archaeologist
definition.description:
An archaeologist learns about the long-lost and fallen cultures of the past by studying their remains — their bones, their ruins, their surviving masterworks, and their tombs. Those who practice archaeology travel to the far corners of the world to root through crumbled cities and lost dungeons, digging in search of artifacts that might tell the stories of monarchs and high priests, wars and cataclysms.

 

Skill Proficiencies: History, Survival
Tool Proficiencies: Cartographer’s tools or navigator’s tools
Languages: One of your choice
Equipment: A wooden case containing a map to a ruin or dungeon, a bullseye lantern, a miner’s pick, a set of traveler’s clothes, a shovel, a two-person tent, a trinket recovered from a dig site, and a pouch containing 25 gp

 

Dust Digger

Prior to becoming an adventurer, you spent most of your young life crawling around in the dust, pilfering relics of questionable value from crypts and ruins. Though you managed to sell a few of your discoveries and earn enough coin to buy proper adventuring gear, you have held onto an item that has great emotional value to you. Roll on the Signature Item table to see what you have, or choose an item from the table.

Signature Item

d8 Item   d8 Item
1 10-foot pole   5 Medallion
2 Crowbar   6 Shovel
3 Hat   7 Sledgehammer
4 Hooded lantern   8 Whip
 


FEATURE HISTORICAL KNOWLEDGE

When you enter a ruin or dungeon, you can correctly ascertain its original purpose and determine its builders, whether those were dwarves, elves, humans, yuan-ti, or some other known race. In addition, you can determine the monetary value of art objects more than a century old.

 

Suggested Characteristics

Few archaeologists can resist the lure of an unexplored ruin or dungeon, particularly if such a site is the source of legends or is rumored to contain the treasures and relics of wizards, warlords, or royalty. Some archaeologists plunder for wealth or fame, while others consider it their calling to illuminate the past or keep the world’s greatest treasures from falling into the wrong hands. Whatever their motivations, archaeologists combine the qualities of a scrappy historian with the self-made heroism of a treasure-hunting scoundrel.

d8 Personality Trait
1 I love a good puzzle or mystery.
2 I’m a pack rat who never throws anything away.
3 Fame is more important to me than money.
4 I have no qualms about stealing from the dead.
5 I’m happier in a dusty old tomb than I am in the centers of civilization.
6 Traps don’t make me nervous. Idiots who trigger traps make me nervous.
7 I might fail, but I will never give up.
8 You might think I’m a scholar, but I love a good brawl. These fists were made for punching.
d6 Ideal
1 Preservation. That artifact belongs in a museum. (Good)
2 Greed. I won’t risk my life for nothing. I expect some kind of payment. (Any)
3 Death Wish. Nothing is more exhilarating than a narrow escape from the jaws of death. (Chaotic)
4 Dignity. The dead and their belongings deserve to be treated with respect. (Lawful)
5 Immortality. All my exploring is part of a plan to find the secret of everlasting life. (Any)
6 Danger. With every great discovery comes grave danger. The two walk hand in hand. (Any)
d6 Bond
1 Ever since I was a child, I’ve heard stories about a lost city. I aim to find it, learn its secrets, and earn my place in the history books.
2 I want to find my mentor, who disappeared on an expedition some time ago.
3 I have a friendly rival. Only one of us can be the best, and I aim to prove it’s me.
4 I won’t sell an art object or other treasure that has historical significance or is one of a kind.
5 I’m secretly in love with the wealthy patron who sponsors my archaeological exploits.
6 I hope to bring prestige to a library, a museum, or a university.
d6 Flaw
1 I have a secret fear of some common wild animal—and in my work, I see them everywhere.
2 I can’t leave a room without searching it for secret doors.
3 When I’m not exploring dungeons or ruins, I get jittery and impatient.
4 I have no time for friends or family. I spend every waking moment thinking about and preparing for my next expedition.
5 When given the choice of going left or right, I always go left.
6 I can’t sleep except in total darkness.
definition.shortDescription: An archaeologist learns about the long-lost and fallen cultures of the past by studying their remains — their bones, their ruins, their surviving masterworks, and their tombs. Those who practice archaeology travel to the far corners of the world to root through crumbled cities and lost dungeons, digging in search of artifacts that might tell the stories of monarchs and high priests, wars and cataclysms.

In addition, you can determine the monetary value of art objects more than a century old.

Some archaeologists plunder for wealth or fame, while others consider it their calling to illuminate the past or keep the world’s greatest treasures from falling into the wrong hands. Whatever their motivations, archaeologists combine the qualities of a scrappy historian with the self-made heroism of a treasure-hunting scoundrel.

race.description:
Hailing from a strange and distant land, wandering tabaxi are catlike humanoids driven by curiosity to collect interesting artifacts, gather tales and stories, and lay eyes on all the world’s wonders.

Racial Traits
+2 Dexterity, +1 Charisma, Darkvision, Feline Agility, Cat's Claws, Cat's Talent

definition.name: Ability Score Increase
definition.description: Your Dexterity score increases by 2, and your Charisma score increases by 1.

definition.name: Age
definition.description: Tabaxi have lifespans equivalent to humans.

definition.name: Alignment
definition.description: Tabaxi tend toward chaotic alignments, as they let impulse and fancy guide their decisions. They are rarely evil, with most of them driven by curiosity rather than greed or other dark impulses.

definition.name: Size
definition.description: Tabaxi are taller on average than humans and relatively slender. Your size is Medium.

definition.name: Speed
definition.description: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

definition.name: Darkvision
definition.description: You have a cat’s keen senses, especially in the dark. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
definition.snippet: You can see in darkness (shades of gray) up to 60 ft.

definition.name: Feline Agility
definition.description: Your reflexes and agility allow you to move with a burst of speed. When you move on your turn in combat, you can double your speed until the end of the turn. Once you use this trait, you can’t use it again until you move 0 feet on one of your turns.
definition.snippet: When you move on your turn in combat, you can double your speed until the end of the turn. Once you use this trait, you can’t use it again until you move 0 feet on one of your turns.

definition.name: Cat’s Claws
definition.description: Because of your claws, you have a climbing speed of 20 feet. In addition, your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal slashing damage equal to 1d4 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.
definition.snippet: You have a climbing speed of 20 ft. and your claws are natural weapons that deal 1d4 {{modifier:str}} slashing damage, instead of the normal bludgeoning damage for an unarmed strike.

definition.name: Cat’s Talent
definition.description: You have proficiency in the Perception and Stealth skills.
definition.snippet: You have proficiency in the Perception and Stealth skills.

definition.name: Languages
definition.description: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language of your choice.

notes.personalPossessions:
a wooden case containing a map to a ruin or dungeon
a mysterious silver locket which I have found on one of my former expeditions

traits.personalityTraits:
I love a good puzzle or mystery.
I have no qualms about stealing from the dead.
I’m happier in a dusty old tomb than I am in the centers of civilization.
Traps don’t make me nervous. Idiots who trigger traps make me nervous.

Preservation. That artifact belongs in a museum. (Good)

Immortality. All my exploring is part of a plan to find the secret of everlasting life. (Any)
Danger. With every great discovery comes grave danger. The two walk hand in hand. (Any)
traits.bonds:
Ever since I was a child, I’ve heard stories about a lost city. I aim to find it, learn its secrets, and earn my place in the history books.
I hope to bring prestige to a library, a museum, or a university.
traits.flaws:
I have no time for friends or family. I spend every waking moment thinking about and preparing for my next expedition.
When given the choice of going left or right, I always go left.

definition.name: Leather
definition.description: The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description: Proficiency with a dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description: Proficiency with a dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Ammunition
properties.description:
You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield. 
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons" later in the section). A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

properties.name: Range
properties.description: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's long range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

definition.name: Shortbow
definition.description: Proficiency with a shortbow allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

definition.name: Shortsword
definition.description: Proficiency with a shortsword allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

definition.name: Arrows
definition.description: Arrows are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

definition.name: Backpack
definition.description:
A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

definition.name: Clothes, Costume
definition.description: This set of clothes is fashioned after a particular costume, typically meant for entertaining.

definition.name: Clothes, Traveler's
definition.description: This set of clothes could consist of boots, a wool skirt or breeches, a sturdy belt, a shirt (perhaps with a vest or jacket), and an ample cloak with a hood.

definition.name: Crowbar
definition.description: Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbar's leverage can be applied.

definition.name: Hammer
definition.description: This one-handed hammer with an iron head is useful for pounding pitons into a wall.

definition.name: Lantern, Bullseye
definition.description: A bullseye lantern casts bright light in a 60-foot cone and dim light for an additional 60 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.

definition.name: Pick, Miner's
definition.description: A miner's pick is designed to concentrate the force of its blow on a small area.

definition.name: Piton
definition.description: When a wall doesn’t offer handholds and footholds, you can make your own. A piton is a steel spike with an eye through which you can loop a rope.

definition.name: Rations (1 day)
definition.description: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

definition.name: Rope, Hempen (50 feet)
definition.description: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

definition.name: Shovel
definition.description: A standard shovel used for digging.

definition.name: Tent, Two-Person
definition.description: A simple and portable canvas shelter, a tent sleeps two.

definition.name: Tinderbox
definition.description: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

definition.name: Torch
definition.description: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

definition.name: Waterskin
definition.description: A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.

definition.name: Thieves' Tools
definition.description: This set of tools includes a small file, a set of lock picks, a small mirror mounted on a metal handle, a set of narrow-bladed scissors, and a pair of pliers. Proficiency with these tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to disarm traps or open locks.

definition.name: Rain Catcher
definition.description:
A rain catcher is a simple contraption consisting of a 5-foot-square leather tarp and a wooden frame with legs. When the tarp is stretched across the wooden frame, it forms a basin that can catch 2 gallons of drinking water per inch of rainfall and hold up to 8 gallons. The tarp and wooden frame fold up for easy transport.  A rain catcher costs 1 gp and weighs 5 pounds.

Merchant prince Ekene-Afa controls the sale of rain catchers in Port Nyanzaru.

definition.name: Insect Repellent-Salve
definition.description:
Insect repellent can be purchased in Port Nyanzaru in two forms: blocks of incense or a greasy salve. The merchant prince Kwayothé controls the sale of both. Neither kind of repellent protects against giant insects or the vile swarm of insects;swarms of insects described in appendix A of the Monster Manual.

A gourd or vial of salve, which sells for 1 gp, contains 20 applications of odorless grease. One application protects its wearer against normal insects for 24 hours. The salve is waterproof so it doesn’t wash off in rain.

definition.name: Wildroot
definition.description: Introducing the juice of a wildroot into a poisoned creature’s bloodstream (for example, by rubbing it on an open wound) rids the creature of the poisoned condition. Once used in this way, a wildroot loses this property.

definition.name: Rogue
definition.description:
A scoundrel who uses stealth and trickery to overcome obstacles and enemies

Hit Die: d8
Primary Ability: Dexterity
Saves: Dexterity & Intelligence
definition.equipmentDescription:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a rapier or (b) a shortsword
  • (a) a shortbow and quiver of 20 arrows or (b) a shortsword
  • (a) a burglar’s pack, (b) a dungeoneer’s pack, or (c) an explorer’s pack
  • Leather armor, two daggers, and thieves’ tools

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d8 per rogue level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per rogue level after 1st

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: Light armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
Tools: Thieves’ tools
Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence
Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

classFeatures.name: Expertise
classFeatures.description:
At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with thieves’ tools) to gain this benefit.

classFeatures.name: Sneak Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe’s distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.

classFeatures.name: Thieves’ Cant
classFeatures.description:
During your rogue training you learned thieves’ cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves’ cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves’ guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.

classFeatures.name: Cunning Action
classFeatures.description: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

classFeatures.name: Roguish Archetype
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities: Thief, detailed at the end of the class description, or one from another source. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Uncanny Dodge
classFeatures.description: Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack’s damage against you.

classFeatures.name: Expertise
classFeatures.description: At 6th level, choose two more of your skill proficiencies, or one more of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

classFeatures.name: Evasion
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as an ancient red dragon’s fiery breath or an ice storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 10th level, and again at 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Reliable Talent
classFeatures.description: By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Blindsense
classFeatures.description: Starting at 14th level, if you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 feet of you.

classFeatures.name: Slippery Mind
classFeatures.description: By 15th level, you have acquired greater mental strength. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Elusive
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren’t incapacitated.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Stroke of Luck
classFeatures.description:
At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassDefinition.name: Scout
subclassDefinition.description: You are skilled in stealth and surviving far from the streets of a city, allowing you to scout ahead of your companions during expeditions. Rogues who embrace this archetype are at home in the wilderness and among barbarians and rangers, and many Scouts serve as the eyes and ears of war bands. Ambusher, spy, bounty hunter — these are just a few of the roles that Scouts assume as they range the world.

classFeatures.name: Skirmisher
classFeatures.description: Starting at 3rd level, you are difficult to pin down during a fight. You can move up to half your speed as a reaction when an enemy ends its turn within 5 feet of you. This movement doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks.

classFeatures.name: Survivalist
classFeatures.description: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the Nature and Survival skills if you don’t already have it. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of those proficiencies.

classFeatures.name: Superior Mobility
classFeatures.description: At 9th level, your walking speed increases by 10 feet. If you have a climbing or swimming speed, this increase applies to that speed as well.

classFeatures.name: Ambush Master
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 13th level, you excel at leading ambushes and acting first in a fight.

You have advantage on initiative rolls. In addition, the first creature you hit during the first round of a combat becomes easier for you and others to strike; attack rolls against that target have advantage until the start of your next turn.

classFeatures.name: Sudden Strike
classFeatures.description: Starting at 17th level, you can strike with deadly speed. If you take the Attack action on your turn, you can make one additional attack as a bonus action. This attack can benefit from your Sneak Attack even if you have already used it this turn, but you can’t use your Sneak Attack against the same target more than once in a turn.

definition.name: Hit Points
definition.description:
Hit Dice: 1d8 per rogue level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per rogue level after 1st

definition.name: Proficiencies
definition.description:
Armor: Light armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
Tools: Thieves’ tools
Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence
Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth
definition.multiClassDescription:
Armor: Light armor
Tools: Thieves’ tools
Skills: Choose one from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

definition.name: Expertise
definition.description:
At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with thieves’ tools) to gain this benefit.
definition.snippet: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make for two chosen proficiencies. [6th] Choose two additional proficiencies.

definition.name: Sneak Attack
definition.description:
Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe’s distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.
definition.snippet: Once per turn, you can deal an extra {{scalevalue}} damage to one creature you hit with an attack with a finesse or ranged weapon if you have advantage on the attack roll. You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 ft. of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

definition.name: Thieves’ Cant
definition.description:
During your rogue training you learned thieves’ cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves’ cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves’ guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.
definition.snippet: You have learned thieves’ cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

definition.name: Cunning Action
definition.description: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.
definition.snippet: You can take a bonus action on each of your turns to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

definition.name: Skirmisher
definition.description: Starting at 3rd level, you are difficult to pin down during a fight. You can move up to half your speed as a reaction when an enemy ends its turn within 5 feet of you. This movement doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks.
definition.snippet: You can move up to half your speed as a reaction when an enemy ends its turn within 5 ft. of you without provoking opportunity attacks.

definition.name: Survivalist
definition.description: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the Nature and Survival skills if you don’t already have it. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of those proficiencies.
definition.snippet: You gain proficiency in the Nature and Survival skills and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of them.

definition.name: Roguish Archetype
definition.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities: Thief, detailed at the end of the class description, or one from another source. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Uncanny Dodge
definition.description: Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack’s damage against you.
definition.snippet: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack’s damage against you.

definition.name: Expertise
definition.description: At 6th level, choose two more of your skill proficiencies, or one more of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
definition.snippet: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses any of the chosen proficiencies.

definition.name: Evasion
definition.description: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as an ancient red dragon’s fiery breath or an ice storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.
definition.snippet: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a DEX saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Superior Mobility
definition.description: At 9th level, your walking speed increases by 10 feet. If you have a climbing or swimming speed, this increase applies to that speed as well.
definition.snippet: Your walking (and climbing or swimming) speed increases by 10 ft.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 10th level, and again at 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Reliable Talent
definition.description: By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.
definition.snippet: Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ambush Master
definition.description:
Starting at 13th level, you excel at leading ambushes and acting first in a fight.

You have advantage on initiative rolls. In addition, the first creature you hit during the first round of a combat becomes easier for you and others to strike; attack rolls against that target have advantage until the start of your next turn.
definition.snippet: You have advantage on initiative rolls and attack rolls against the first creature you hit during the first round of combat have advantage until the start of your next turn.

definition.name: Blindsense
definition.description: Starting at 14th level, if you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 feet of you.
definition.snippet: If you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 ft. of you.

definition.name: Slippery Mind
definition.description: By 15th level, you have acquired greater mental strength. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.
definition.snippet: You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Sudden Strike
definition.description: Starting at 17th level, you can strike with deadly speed. If you take the Attack action on your turn, you can make one additional attack as a bonus action. This attack can benefit from your Sneak Attack even if you have already used it this turn, but you can’t use your Sneak Attack against the same target more than once in a turn.
definition.snippet: If you take the Attack action on your turn, you can make one additional attack as a bonus action. It can be an additional Sneak Attack even if you have already used it this turn, but only against a new target.

definition.name: Elusive
definition.description: Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren’t incapacitated.
definition.snippet: No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren’t incapacitated.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Stroke of Luck
definition.description:
At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
definition.snippet: Once per short rest, if your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

race.name: Feline Agility
race.snippet: When you move on your turn in combat, you can double your speed until the end of the turn. Once you use this trait, you can’t use it again until you move 0 feet on one of your turns.

race.name: Claws
race.snippet: Your claws are natural weapons that you can use for unarmed strikes that deal 1d4 {{modifier:str}} slashing damage.

class.name: Cunning Action
class.snippet: You can take a bonus action on each of your turns to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

class.name: Skirmisher
class.snippet: You can move up to half your speed as a reaction when an enemy ends its turn within 5 ft. of you without provoking opportunity attacks.

class.name: Sneak Attack
class.description:
Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe’s distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.
class.snippet: Once per turn, you can deal an extra {{scalevalue}} damage to one creature you hit with an attack with a finesse or ranged weapon if you have advantage on the attack roll. You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 ft. of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.
